ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Some seminar or discussion aspects were included, but it was mostly just lecture.
asynchronous pre class components and interactive breakout room time.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: this class was very challenging. it was a continuation of BC Calc. I had to learn a lot about finding sources outside of the course to teach myself because I felt there were a lot of gaps in my knowledge.
I learned much of the subject matter involved in the course.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Did not translate well to zoom. We did not have access to filled in notes which made it very difficult to follow up on concepts. It was very difficult to translate information over zoom since a lot of the concepts were hard to verbally discuss in formulaic terms. 
It was also hard to ask questions without being able to show our work. 

Also very large discrepancies in how each section of the course was taught which was frustrating when all being evaluated similarly.

I had an extremely difficult time engaging with the class or understanding any of the subject matter. I felt very lost for much of the year and would often have to spend additional hours every week reteaching myself the lecture material in order to complete the weekly PSETs.
The teacher was not very good. I had to learn most of the information on my own after classes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Zoom is just not a great format for learning math-it was very hard to convey ideas. 
Jamboard worked fairly well though!
More interactive elements or active participation from students during the zoom calls would have been helpful.
some issues with zoom and writing on slides could be improved.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No. I  would not. THis class was definitely my most frustrating and hardest class not because of the information but because it was not formatted well.
I recommend if you like calculus.
